name: CVP, SVR, PCWP
question1: Describe and draw the CVP trace
question2: Draw a diagram of pressures in the heart.
question3: What is the most important factor determining SVR? What is the equation for SVR? What increases/decreases SVR?
contents3:
• Most important factor determining SVR is the small arterioles = resistance arterioles
  • 100-450µm diameter
  • Pre-capillary arterioles (<100µm) play a less significant role, have autoregulation 
  • Pressure drop across major veins and arteries is similarly small
  • No change in pressure drop when standing vs. supine as pressure in both arteries and veins increases
  • Hepatic portal bed is very low resistance, in comparison to splenic bed


Think V= IR (Ohms law) or R = V/I or potential difference / flow

  • SVR is measured in dynes.s/cm5
  • Normal SVR = 1000 dynes.s.cm-5


  • SVR = (MAP (mmHg) - Mean Right Atrial pressure (mmHg)) x 80 / CO (L/min)
  • Mean right atrial pressure = CVP
  • 80 is to convert mmHg to dynes
  • eg. SVR = 80-8 = 72 x 80 / 5 = 1152 dynes.s.cm-5


SVR may be decreased by:

  • Pregnancy, mediated by progesterone + down-regulation of alpha-receptors
  • Hypercapnia

SVR may be increased by:

  • Arterial hypoxaemia (e.g. in PE), via stimulation of peripheral chemoreceptors in the carotid and aortic bodies
  • Raised ICP
  • Change from foetal to adult circulation



  • Normal PVR = 20-130 dynes.s.cm-5 = approx ⅙ x SVR. (?10 times lower than SVR very non-linear owing to recruitment and distension of vessels in the pulmonary vascular bed.)
  • Similarly, PVR = (MPAP (mmHg) - PCWP (mmHg)) x 80 / CO (L/min)
  • resistance to flow in the pulmonary vasculature against which the right ventricle must contract.
  • MPAP - mean pulmonary artery pressure
  • MLAP = mean left atrial pressure (MLAP can be substituted for PCWP)
  • PVR = (MPAP - MLAP) x 80 / CO
  • PVR = 50-150 dyne.s.cm-5
  • A Swan-Ganz catheter can be used to measure CO and PA pressure = can calculate PVR
  • To account for body size, CO can be replaced by cardiac index (ml/minute/m2) = CO/body surface area; produces parameters SVRI or PVRI
  • Increased by 5-HT
  • Decreased by B2 agonism, e.g. isoprenaline
question4: Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure - draw the trace from RA --> PCWP
contents4:
• RA: (0-5mmHg)
  • identical to the CVP
  • RV: (0-5mmHg / 20-25mmHg)
  • RV pressure waveform should oscillate between 0-5mmHg and 20-25mmHg
  • PA: (10-15mHg / 20-25mmHg)
  • as the catheter moves into the PA the:
  • systolic pressure should stay the same as the RV (20-25mmHg),
  • diastolic pressure should increase to 10-15mmHg - due to the presence of the pulmonary valve.
  • PCWP (6-12mmHg)
  • this must be lower than the PA diastolic pressure to ensure forward flow.
  • it is draw as an undulating waveform similar to the CVP trace. the normal value is 6-12mmHg.
question5: What can cause peripheral oedema? + References:
contents5:
Peripheral oedema may be noted if:

  • (1) Right atrial pressure >10mmHg / 15cmH2O
  • (2) Serum albumin 20g/L
  • (3) Urinary albumin excretion of 12g/24hrs
  • (4) Would need increased ECF volume >500ml to be noticeable
